@stevendeknight My daughter worked at a mid high-end Georgetown restaurant during her graduate studies, a decade and a half ago, so those estimates may be wildly out of whack by now, but the principle is there.

@stevendeknight That guess is based on the base tip for a table of 4 at a high end restaurant, where the table brings $200-400 over an hour. 15% tip (minimum) on average, $45 per table. Waiters cover four to six tables, that‚Äôs $250 in tips an hour at peak, probably averaging $175 over the night.

@stevendeknight My guess is a fair wage for servers should be around $150-200 an hour at high end restaurants during peak hours, ditto for bartenders at high end night clubs. (Based on estimated tipping.) $20-25 an hour at small restaurants seems like a minimum.

@stevendeknight Or we could do like, well, almost every other first world country and pay servers a decent wage and forgo tipping entirely. The whole thing is demeaning at both ends and an excuse for restaurant owners to conceal the full price of a meal.

Once again, Nolan is too clever for his own good. Even upon reviewing it‚Äôs still hard to track the protagonist through the big battle, reducing the emotional stakes of what should have been as powerful a battle scene as the ones in Dunkirk.

By the plot ‚Äúlogic‚Äù embraced to obscure the protagonist‚Äôs face at the beginning, Nolan has to obscure his protagonists‚Äô faces during critical action at the end. Superhero directors learned to NEVER DO THIS, which is why superheroes lose their masks during final battles.

BUT the real purpose is so he can disguise the Protagonist‚Äôs dual identity during the big duel in the first half. Without a face-hiding mask the whole plot would be given away. But that plot choice then traps him into a poor filmmaking conclusion:

I‚Äôm talking about the face masks the characters wear in the climactic battle, which make it nearly impossible to identify who is doing what during crucial moments. Nolan provides an in-world excuse (a blah blah about not being able to breathe regular air) but‚Ä¶

Recently rewatched ‚ÄúTenet‚Äù (and if you have HBOMax now you can watch it for the first or second time too) and while I liked it more on second viewing, one huge filmmaking problem remains‚Äî a direct result of a choice Christopher Nolan had to make to conceal his central conceit.

Great Cthulhu preserve me. This is what happens when you mess with timelines.
The expansion came out only six years ago. Am I losing it or is this some personal version of the Mandela Effect?

I'm halfway through the expansion (it takes about a week in Tourist Mode per expansion, a couple of hours a day) and I still have no memory of playing WoD before I get to each "new" Zone. This. Is. So. Weird.

Before entering a zone in WoD I have no idea what I'm going to find -- and then as I'm playing I realize, yeah, I've done this. I keep thinking I must have quit halfway through the Zone I'm in but nope, I did the whole thing. Maybe I quit before the next Zone. But, nope.
But I have NO MEMORY OF DOING SO.
And that's when things get weird. As I started playing WoD I had the feeling events and quests were...familiar. Very familiar. And I began to realize -- I've played this expansion.

See, I thought the expansion that finished my interest in WoW was Mists of Panderia, which came out in 2012. So when I got to MoP I basically just hit the high points, soloed the dungeons and raids (where I could) and looked forward to the next expansion, Warlords of Draenor.

Having the weirdest experience with my replay of WoW. As I've mentioned I'm currently replaying WoW in Tourist Mode (at top level so every lower zone is basically a one-shot walk through). It's been nostalgic fun. But now it's gotten...weird...

Because we'd made a deal to write a script for Fox, we wrote a script called "The Last Warriors," about, uh, seven warriors of the future who gather together to fight an alien invasion. It was kinda pointless. Never got made. But.
This was the year "The Terminator," "Back to the Future" and "Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home" came out.
This was 1984.
"Science Fiction should look like Science Fiction in every frame," he explained. Audiences would never accept time travel movies.

We pointed out that without the "time travel angle" the story was literally then just...Seven Samurai, but, like, in the future. He insisted audiences wouldn't "get" time travel. Especially time travel to The Past. It wouldn't be Science Fiction.
"Can you drop the time travel angle?"

TBF, it isn't the movie we ended up writing because the Head Idiot in the Fox executive suite hated the idea of time travel movies. (Our premise was basically "Seven Samurai with Time Travel", warriors from different eras.) So after buying the pitch he asked for One Small Change.

To conclude, this is the movie I wish MoS and BvS would have been. Bravo.

Overall, I can't see what WB's issues with this take could have been. It's got humor, the tone isn't as dark as either previous film, it has heart, and it's epically triumphant. If this is what Snyder was giving them they were idiots not to see what they had.

The film *is* over-long, but given Snyder's purpose with this cut, that's simple to forgive. I imagine his preferred theatrical cut would have clocked in at 3 hours. WB's apparent insistence on a two-hour cut would have been (and was) butchery.

I still feel Snyder should have created a wide-screen cut but the square format didn't bother me as much as I thought it might -- I stopped noticing it fairly quickly. If @wbpictures doesn't release this to IMAX they're missing an easy money bet. This deserves a big screen.

I don't know whether it was because of WB's demand for a much shorter film, and the necessity that created for reshoots to elipsize chunks of plot, which in turn rushed the CGI work, but, boy, does this "rebuilt" cut kick ass visually.

I also understand why Ray Fisher was so upset by the "restructuring" of the film (aside from his reports of abusive behavior): The major human emotional arc of this film  belongs to Victor Stone, and its loss in the theatrical JL cuts the heart out of the story.

Spoiler free reaction to Zack Snyder's JL: I wish the man who made this movie had made "Man of Steel" and "BvS". Maybe Snyder took to heart some of the criticism of those two movies, because tonally this is a different piece-- a paean to the power of hope and healing.

We'll see how Snyder's vision plays out next month.

IMHO Snyder is a creator whose "artistic vision" seems to depend on undermining audience expectations. In the hands of film geniuses like Welles, Hitchcock, Kubrick, Fincher, this can lead to insight and a heightened artistic experience.

Yes, I know it was shot that way, but it was Snyder's *choice* to frame his shots so that reformatting to a different aspect ratio would downgrade the aesthetic experience. He could have done it differently. He chose to box himself in.

The most natural format for film visual perception is horizontal. Designing a film to be viewed in a square format (especially knowing it cannot be shown as an IMAX presentation) is a bizzare and  bewildering aesthetic choice.

...human visual perception is based on a *binocular* field of view, explicitly, a *horizontal* visual field. Our attentive focus is lateral, not vertical. We perceive objects from "the corner of our eye"-- not from above or below.

The IMAX "square" format works as a theatrical presentation format only because the screen is (supposed to be) larger than typical theatrical presentation screens, and thus the image fills the visual field of the human eye, enhancing perception. OTOH...

As I said before, an artist is entitled to have his or her presented as he or she intended, so if Zack Snyder wants to present his JL on TV in a format designed for a specific theatrical presentation not applicable to television, well, okay. But.

So, good on you, @DCComics ‚Äî embrace the crazy. I may be frustrated occasionally by what feels like an unnecessary reboot, but you do you.
My attitude then and now is that if the story is entertaining and makes sense internally IT DOESN‚ÄôT MATTER.

At the time I got heat from continuity nerds because I made no attempt to rationalize the characters meeting. What ‚Äúuniverse‚Äù was this happening in? How was it possible? Where were the interspatial portals and the framistans that hobwinked the kyniscopes?

DC‚Äôs approach fits my personal philosophy that stories are stories and you can tell any story you want if you acknowledge it‚Äôs all make believe anyway. It‚Äôs how I approached the ‚ÄúSuperman vs Spider-Man‚Äù crossover.
Both approaches have their uses but honestly I‚Äôm more impressed and entertained by DC‚Äôs apparent ‚Äúf**k it, what are you gonna do?‚Äù attitude.

@DCComics OTOH seems to have unconsciously embraced the reality that their ‚ÄúDC Universe‚Äù continuity is totally f**ked and is no longer even pretending to deal with it. DC seems to be saying, hey, deal with it.

Yep. #FoxNews is the #buttake of political discourse.
A lot of people already believe what #FoxNews is telling them about Christianity and white supremacy, just as a lot of men believe what #Pornhub shows about women wanting guys to cum on their face.

So when we blame #FoxNews for encouraging white supremacy we‚Äôre missing the forest for the forest fire. In reality #FoxNews, like #Pornhub, has allowed us to identify a truth we might find uncomfortable but need to accept:

#FoxNews and #Pornhub are expressions of market influenced programming, a perfect free market in action, a version of pure capitalism in its most base form. Viewers vote with their attention. If the market for #SeanHannity and #bondageporn wasn‚Äôt strong, neither would exist.

IMHO, while one might stumble across #Pornhub‚Äôs most misogynistic videos by accident, just as one might stumble onto an episode of #TuckerCarlson‚Äôs show, one doesn‚Äôt keep watching or return again and again unless the buttake or Carlson appeals to some pre-existing disposition.

Even a casual survey of the most popular videos on #Pornhub would convince anyone that the site‚Äôs most ardent viewer base has a very low opinion of female independence and sexual worth. Did #Pornhub create that mindset?

No one is forced to watch #FoxNews just as no one is forced to troll #Pornhub for buttake videos. People watch #FoxNews for the same reason misogynists devour hours of women-demeaning videos on #Pornhub: it panders to their pre-existing prejudices and subconscious needs.

Thinking about #FoxNews. Yes, it‚Äôs terrible. Yes, it should be eliminated as a social good. But it did not create right wing racist conspiracy thought, any more than #Pornhub created sexual misogyny. Like #Pornhub, #Foxnews simply panders to a market reality.

The time for legislative paralysis is long past. Democrats and Republicans both have a right to see their policy preferences enacted into law. Instead of arguing about what the other side *might* do let‚Äôs argue about what it *did.* #EndTheFilibuster

Congress must #legislate. Let Republicans and Democrats fulfill their campaign promises and then let voters decide which laws reflect the country‚Äôs wishes. By abandoning the responsibility of passing legislation through the #filibuster both parties escape #Accountability.
The argument some used to make that the #filibuster would prevent #Republicans from passing laws progressives hate makes no sense if it also prevents #Democrats from passing laws progressives want.

Many Senators, #Democrats and #Republicans alike, prefer a #filibuster regime that allows them an excuse to avoid voting on proposals they promote but know can never pass. This must stop. We need Senatorial #Accountability too.

The truth is, the #filibuster exists to provide both leverage to a minority that wants to frustrate the majority will AND to provide cover for political cowardice on the part of Senators who don‚Äôt wish to take tough votes that would expose them to political pressure.

In that context, a Senate that is designed to tilt power to a minority of the population, a #filibuster that gives even more power to even fewer people is so completely anti-democratic it‚Äôs laughably indefensible.

Because the Senate was deliberately designed to weight less populous or smaller states as equal in power to more populous and larger states, it is fundamentally an undemocratic institution. It already favors more power to the minority than the majority.

The anti-democratic origin of the Senate is further shown by the original Constitutional mechanism for selecting Senators: they were to be appointed, not elected, by the legislature of each state. That was changed only a little over 100 years ago with the 17th Amendment.

When the Constitution was negotiated, small states like Rhode Island feared being swept aside by the electoral power of large states like Virginia. So as a sop to less populated states the Senate was created to provide anti-democratic ‚Äúbalance‚Äù.

An important fact to remember is that the Senate does not represent the American people, nor was it intended to (that‚Äôs the House of Representatives): the Senate represents the individual American states. As such it‚Äôs inherently undemocratic and tilts conservative.

Still, that experience of embracing conservative ideas gives me perspective to recognize the Republican Party has not been a *conservative* party for decades. It is a cynical organization devoted solely to the advancement of wealthy elites through the manipulation of racism.

I‚Äôm not ashamed of my brief late ‚Äò70s flirtation with conservative thought. At the time I believed the ideas presented were worth exploring given the apparent failure of liberal policies. When conservative policies also failed, I rethought my position. That‚Äôs what you do.

Today, there is no real conservative intellectual basis to the #GOP, no brilliant conservative theorists offering fresh new solutions to genuine national problems. Denial that there are social and economic problems is the current Republican orthodoxy.

Even the party‚Äôs bogus embrace of ‚ÄúChristianity‚Äù was race based, since the Christians the party most ostentatiously embraced where White Fundamentalists. Fewer and fewer Republican policies were more than window-dressed with conservative ‚Äúprinciples‚Äù.

Instead of arguing for conservative principles, as their intellectual elites like Friedman, Sowell, and Podhoretz did, Republican politicians embraced increasingly divisive race-baiting to win elections.  By the mid-1990s, race was the unspoken but defining Republican issue.

By the mid-80s, particularly after the Reagan Recession and his vicious busting of the Air Traffic Controllers Union, I came to see conservative ‚Äúpolicy‚Äù as window dressing for the GOP‚Äôs real goal: accumulating power and pandering to wealthy donors.

Instead of boosting the middle class and producing a more fair and just society, the conservative paradigm embraced by both political parties in the 1980s and 1990s led to a collapse of the middle class, ruinous national debt (except under 2nd term Clinton) and social unrest.

As it turned out, conservative economic theory was just as flawed as the calcified liberal economic theory of the 1970s. Or maybe both theories were just poorly executed. Or maybe economic theories have little to do with the real world.

With high unemployment and high inflation and high interest rates, the late 1970s seemed to expose fatal flaws in the liberal economic paradigm. Conservative thought offered potential answers. I thought it was worth trying.

In the late 1970s, conservative methods were portrayed as an alternative means to the same progressive goal‚Äî a more just society, fairer to individuals, with more opportunities for growth than what appeared to be dead-end liberal programs.

I had disagreements with my progressive friends. I remained committed to my progressive goals but I believed the failures of what was clearly calcified liberal policies in the 1970s offered a reason to explore conservative alternatives.

In the late 1970s, early 1980s, before the evidence of policy failure was incontrovertible, I embraced many of what were then bold ideas from the conservative movement. I read ‚ÄúCommentary,‚Äù read Milton Friedman and Thomas Slowell, read Buckley‚Äôs ‚ÄúNational Review‚Äù.
